Made my shifting woodlands a copy of druid class two turns in a row. Why does it remember that it was leveled up?

Because the level is a designation that a permanent can have. Even if it stops being a class card, it remembers what level it was at, so if it copies another class card, it starts out at that level.

> 716.2b A level is a designation that any permanent can have. **A Class retains its level even if it stops being a Class.** Levels are not a copiable characteristic.

Returning multiple enchantments with triggered abilities to battlefield from graveyard

I had this question answered by a judge one time, but I'm sort of fuzzy on how/why this actually works.

Say I have \[\[Doomwake Giant\]\] \[\[Forgeborn Oreads\]\] and \[\[Vicious Shadows\]\] in my graveyard, and then I reolve a spell like \[\[Resurgent Belief\]\] or \[\[Replenish\]\] what happens with the triggered abilities? If I understood correctly, these spells are "in play" and so they count eachother for their triggered abilities. I.e. my opponents' creatures get -3/-3 from Doomwake Giant, I get to do 3 damage to any target(s) from Forgeborn, and then I get a Vicious Shadows Trigger for each creature that dies as a consequence. Is this correct and what is the reason?

> what happens with the triggered abilities?  
  
They go on the stack and then resolve.  
  
> these spells   
  
Those aren't spells, those are cards in the graveyard and then permanents on the battlefield.  
  
- 112.1. A *spell* is a card on the stack. [..]  
 - 112.1a. A copy of a spell is also a spell, even if it has no card associated with it.   
 - 112.1b. Some effects allow a player to cast a copy of a card; if the player does, that copy is a spell as well.   
  
The only spell in your scenario is either Resurgent Belief or Replenish.  
  
The game checks for triggers immediately following the EtB event.  
  
- 603.10. Normally, objects that exist immediately after an event are checked to see if the event matched any trigger conditions, and continuous effects that exist at that time are used to determine what the trigger conditions are and what the objects involved in the event look like. [..]  
  
> they count each other for their triggered abilities  
  
Yes, and themselves.    
  
>  my opponents' creatures get -3/-3 from Doomwake Giant, I get to do 3 damage to any target(s) from Forgeborn, and then I get a Vicious Shadows Trigger for each creature that dies as a consequence. Is this correct and what is the reason?  
  
Yes.

Does his starfall ability counts As commander damage?

Hi, my friend come with this commander and we don't know if his ability counts to commander damage. Thanks for answers

Damage that occurs in the combat phase isn't necessarily "combat damage".  
  
For example: casting Lightning Bolt in the combat phase doesn't make it combat damage.  
  
Combat damage only occurs as a result of the turn-based action in combat damage steps of the combat phase, specifically by attacking and blocking creatures.  
Nothing else is combat damage.

Does this work?

I have kiora,imoti and roaming throne naming merfolk on the board, i then cast a 7 mana kraken.
Kiora and imoti both trigger, i make imoti go first and if i cascade into a 6 mana creature, then i get to cascade again.
Then kiora triggers and i cast another 6 mana creature which cascades once again.
And then it last part happens again because of roaming throne.
Is the whole thing correct?

You cast a 7-mana Kraken. Kiora triggers; due to Roaming Throne, it triggers twice. Imoti grants the Kraken spell cascade, and that cascade also triggers. You may put the triggers on the stack in any order.

Stack: (bottom) Kraken spell -> Kiora trigger (MV 7) -> Kiora trigger (MV 7) -> Cascade (MV 7)

The cascade ability resolves, you cascade into a MV 6 creature, let's say [Summon: Leviathan](https://scryfall.com/card/fin/77/summon:-leviathan) (it's just appropriate). It's cast from exile, so Kiora doesn't trigger even if the type is correct. But Imoti does grant it cascade again.

Stack: (bottom) Kraken spell -> Kiora trigger (MV 7) -> Kiora trigger (MV 7) -> Summon spell -> Cascade (MV 6)

You need to take care of the cascade and the spell first, before you can start doing Kiora triggers. Let's say you cascade to something (it doesn't matter since it won't cascade again), then the Summon spell resolves.

Stack: (bottom) Kraken spell -> Kiora trigger (MV 7) -> Kiora trigger (MV 7)

Kiora trigger resolves. You look at the top 7 cards of your library, you get to cast something with MV less than 7. Let's say, oh, you have another Summon: Leviathan. It's cast from your library, so it doesn't trigger Kiora, but it does have cascade from Imoti.

Stack: (bottom) Kraken spell -> Kiora trigger (MV 7) -> Summon spell -> Cascade (MV 6)

And again, you deal with all that before you get to the other Kiora trigger.

---

I think you might have misread Kiora; it only triggers for spells from your hand, so none of the cascades will trigger Kiora at all. But the cascades do trigger their own cascades. When the stack is messy, get a whiteboard or something.

Ruling question

I had my graveyard filled with my whole deck. My opponent used the Ashiok ability targeting myself. With the first part of the ability I milled Syr Konrad, considering I had Colossal Grave-Reaver on the battlefield, do I return Syr Konrad to my battlefield ? How do "then" ability are sequenced ? Can triggered abilities triggers before the second part of the Ashiok's ability ?

> How are "then" abilities sequenced ?  
  
"then" is non-functional in Magic cards.   
It's a clarifier of sequence, but the occurrences are already sequential unless otherwise specified per the rules.  
  
- 608.2c. The controller of the spell or ability follows its instructions in the order written.[..]    
  
However, the gist of what you are asking involves encapsulation of the instructions of the resolving Ashiok activation.  
  
Triggered abilities that trigger while an object is resolving wait to go on the stack after it finished resolving completely.  
  
- 603.2. Whenever a game event or game state matches a triggered ability's trigger event, that ability automatically triggers. The ability doesn't do anything at this point.  
- 603.3. Once an ability has triggered, its controller puts it on the stack as an object that's not a card the next time a player would receive priority. [..]
  
So... you mill, CGR triggers and waits, they exile your graveyard, CGR trigger goes on the stack, your opponent gets priority.  
  
> do I return Syr Konrad to my battlefield ?  
  
Nope, that object no longer exists to be returned.  
The set of objects resulting from the mill were exiled with the other cards so the trigger has an empty set to choose from on resolution.
  
> Can triggered abilities triggers before the second part of the Ashiok's ability ?  
  
Yes, but they won't go on the stack nor resolve until after.

Quantum Riddler and multiple cards draw replacement effect.

AP controls a [[Quantum Riddler]] and a [[Chains of Mephistopheles]] .
What happens with these situations?

i) AP casts [[Think Twice]] with 2 cards in their hand.
ii) AP casts [[Think Twice]] with 1 card in their hand.
iii) AP casts [[Quick Study]] with 2 cards in their hand.
iv) AP casts [[Quick Study]] with 1 card in their hand.

> AP casts Think Twice with 2 cards in their hand.    
  
Is Think Twice one of the two cards or is it two in hand after casting Think Twice?  
  
I'll answer based on the former because I suspect that's what you intended.  
  
AP chooses whether to apply Riddler or Chains first.  
If they apply Riddler, the event becomes draw two cards, which becomes draw 1, draw 1 and Chains applies to the first draw which becomes discard, then draw and then Chains applies to the second which becomes discard, then draw so effectively: discard, draw, discard, draw.  
If they apply Chains, the event becomes discard, then draw and then Riddler applies to the draw so effectively: discard, draw, draw.  
  
>  AP casts Think Twice with 1 card in their hand.  
  
AP chooses to apply Chains or Riddler first.  
If they apply Riddler, event becomes draw 2, then Chains applies to each draw and it becomes mill and mill because there are no cards to discard.  
If they apply Chains, it becomes mill because there are no cards to discard.  
  
> AP casts Quick Study with 2 cards in their hand.  
  
AP has to apply Riddler first per 121.2a, event becomes draw 3.  
Then becomes draw, draw, draw which Chains applies to each and makes it: discard, draw, discard, draw, discard, draw.  
  
> AP casts Quick Study with 1 card in their hand.  

AP has to apply Riddler first per 121.2a, event becomes draw 3.    
Then becomes draw, draw, draw which Chains applies to each and makes it: mill, mill, mill.  
  
In summary...  
  
I -> choice of *discard, draw, discard, draw* or *discard, draw, draw*  
II -> choice of *mill, mill* or *mill*  
III -> *discard, draw, discard, draw, discard, draw*  
IV -> *mill, mill, mill*

Snapcaster Mage and Splicer’s Skill

If I cast [[Snapcaster Mage]] and I target [[Apostle’s Blessing]] in my graveyard targeting [[Precursor Golem]] and its two golems on the battlefield, 1. Can I pay Phyrexian mana as part of the flashback cost? And 2. Can I splice [[Splicer’s Skill]] onto the Apostle’s Blessing by revealing it from my hand and paying its cost to get 3 more golem tokens?

Yes and No.

1. Snapcaster Mage gives Apostle's Blessing "Flashback {1}{W/P}" until end of turn. You have the same options to pay that cost (mana or life) that you have when casting Blessing for its mana cost.
2. Up until Modern Horizons, it seems the answer to your second question would have been yes. But then there was a rules change to splice, and it is now considered a text-changing effect (CR 702.47c). Text-changing effects are not copied when you copy a spell (CR 707.2.), so the copies of Apostle's Blessing would not have the "Create a 3/3 colorless Phyrexian Golem artifact creature token." text. You can splice onto the flashbacked spell, but you would only create 1 golem token in total.

Gift of immortality

Edit: thank you for all the answers. I was an idiot in highschool and am happy to say that it does work the way i thought upon rereading the cards nowadays. Again thank you all for tge clarification.

Im looking at some of my old decks from highschool and im trying to figure out if i was playing this ruling correctly. I tried googling it but what i can find online is a lot of discourse about which one triggers and not about what happens when you structure the interactions this way.

I have a "Loyal Cathar" on the field, and i enchant it with "Gift of Imortality". It dies and i prioritize gift's effect, bringing back my cathar. Loyal Cathar then dies again. At the beginning of the end step i prioritize Loyal Cathars effect, it returns to the battlefield transformed into Unhallowed Cathar. Gift then triggers, going on the stack to come back. 

Since the instance of the cathar returns/transfoms into its backside, does gift see the turned cathar and enchant it again, or does it count as a new instance. I think my confusion comes from the fact that it returns/transforms, and i know that gift doesnt care about transforms (for example, im pretty sure enchanting Unhallowed cathar with gift would bring back Loyal cathar and enchant it again does work). This question also applies to undying, where if you do gift first then the undying return does it see the returned card?

> does gift see the turned cathar and enchant it again?  
  
No.  
The object the trigger was tracking no longer exists so Gift just remains in the yard.  
  
> does it count as a new instance?  
  
It is two objects removed from it.  
It became a new object in the graveyard and then a new object when returned transformed.  
  
- 400.7. An object that moves from one zone to another becomes a new object with no memory of, or relation to, its previous existence. [..]  
  
> if you do gift first then the undying return does it see the returned card?   
  
If it dies, is returned by the Gift trigger and then dies again and is returned by Undying, Gift will stay in the graveyard.

Can you make any creature an aura?

1. I control [[calming licid]], [[grizzly bears]] and [[leyline of anticipation]]

2. I tap calming licid, targetting my opponent's [[camel]].

3. With the licid trigger still on the stack I flash in [[exchange of words]], upon etb targeting the licid and grizzy bears.

4. The licid trigger attempts to resolve, what happens? 

My assumption is that the licid effect resolves as normal, and by the time you gain priority again exchange of words effect has already been nullified due to the licid no longer being a creature.

My hope is that the grizzy bear gets the licid ability. And if that is the case, can I attach the grizzly bear to something and then sac the exchange of words for another weird effect? If this method does not work is there a way to turn other permanents into auras?

Grizzly Bears and the Licid will still be creatures when Exchange of Words try to resolve, so it will resolve. They're still both creatures afterwards.

Then the ability of the Licid tries to resolve, and its target is still valid so it resolves. The Licid becomes an Enchantment Aura with Enchant creature, and ceases to be a creature. It enchants the Camel. Having lost its text box though, it lost the abilities written in it, and so it does nothing to the enchanted Camel. It's just an aura that sits there. You can still pay the cost to unattach the Licid and have it become a creature again, but it won't have any abilities afterwards.

The Grizzly Bears do get the Licid's abilities, and it can activate it to enchant any creature (and cease to be a creature). The enchanted creature won't be able to attack. You may pay the cost to unattach the Grizzlis, and you also may pay the cost to attach it to another creature instead.

Echo effects and Oath of ghouls

Hello, I tried to find information about this interaction but didnt find anything.


Say my opponent and I both have zero creatures in the graveyard and I have an Oath of ghouls in play and a creature with Echo. 

My upkeep starts. Can I order triggers such I decide not to pay the echo cost, so the creature sacrifices itself, and then in that same upkeep I return it to my hand with the trigger of Oath which I had on the stack?


Thanks!!

No. Oath of Ghouls says (annotated):

> At the beginning of each player’s upkeep, that player chooses **target player (a) whose graveyard has fewer creature cards in it than their graveyard does and (b) is their opponent**. [...]

The target player must satisfy both conditions, at the time you choose targets. When you choose targets, you and your opponent both have 0 creature cards in graveyard. So you cannot choose your opponent as the target, as that choice doesn't satisfy (a).

What Oath of Ghouls does *not* say is, it doesn't target the creature card. So if you have 1 creature card and they have 0, then you *can* choose your opponent as target, and let the echo trigger resolve first and then return the sacrificed creature into your hand (instead of the creature already in your graveyard). That can work. But again, you need to be able to target the opponent in the first place.

Also, wow that card's phrasing is confusing.

Caesar, Legion's Emperor - Ability Timing

Caesar's ability reads as follows

>Whenever you attack, you may sacrifice another creature.  
When you do, choose two   
\- Create two 1/1 red and white Soldier creature tokens with haste that are tapped and attacking.  
\- You draw a card and you lose 1 life.  
\- Caesar deals damage equal to the number of creature tokens you control to target opponent.

My main concern is the timing of "Whenever you attack, you may sacrifice another creature."

1. Can I do all this (including the two modes I choose) within my Declare Attackers phase and not necessarily at the end of the Declare Attackers phase? Which means I can declare additional attackers even after resolving Caesar's abilities? Example:
   1. I declare a Human token as an attacker
   2. I sacrifice the aforementioned attacking Human token as well
   3. I choose two modes of Caesar and resolve both
   4. **(Is this legal?)** *I declare my other creatures as attackers as well*
2. Until when can I sacrifice another creature? Must the sacrifice be done immediately, during a specific step, or as long as it's in the combat phase, or maybe even during my turn? Example:
   1. I declare a Human token as an attacker
   2. We move to the Declare Blockers/Combat damage phase
   3. Opponent kills the attacking Human token either via blocking damage or instant abilities
   4. **(Is this legal?)** *I sacrifice the attacking Human token first and trigger my two modes*
      1. *And am I understanding correctly that if this were legal, my two tapped and attacking tokens won't be included in combat this turn?*

I'm about a month into MTG and am learning the rules as much as I can, but this specific ability confuses me since it isn't as straightforward as the others. The other posts about this did help me understand Caesar more, but these two specific cases are kind of difficult for me to break down.

1. The sequence you give is not allowed.  In a declare attackers step, an ability that triggers when a creature attacks can trigger only once _all_ attackers have been declared in that step (C.R. 508.1k, 508.1m).
2. In general, if a triggered ability triggers during a step or phase, it can resolve only during that step or phase. Thus, the ability of [[Caesar, Legion's Emperor]] and the "When you do..." ability it generates can trigger and resolve only during the declare attackers step (before blockers are declared), just as [[Herald of Faith]]'s triggered ability can trigger and resolve only during the declare attackers step. See also: https://www.reddit.com/r/mtgrules/comments/1m0maey/sephiroth_timing/

    For Caesar's ability, the choice to sacrifice a creature is made when the ability resolves, not when it triggers or goes on the stack (C.R. 608.2d).

Truss, Chief Engineer and Planeswalkers

I've read the rulings for Truss and I'm not completely sure on how it works with Planeswalkers ability costs. Can I make the cost "higher" from -6 to -3 by removing 3 hack counters for example?

  
I know it says I can't reduce to less than one, but how does that work with already negative numbers? My guess is that you can't reduce further to -7 but you could go the opposite way to make it easier to activate the ability.

  
Thanks in advance

Well, making -6 go to -3 isn't reducing it, so I would say your reading is correct.

That being said: Truss is a silver-bordered/acorn card, which tend to play fast and loose with the rules and which are not legal by default in any formats. As such, most of them *do not* have official rulings at all - so if you're looking for Official Explicit Confirmation In Wizards Of The Coast's Own Words that say what happens here, then you're gonna be looking forever. Generally the assumption you make with these cards is that the 'reasonable' interpretation of how the card works is correct.
